text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ male with an extensive peripheral vascular surgical history including a failed left fem pop bypass with PTFE culminating in a left above knee amputation. After his amputation he was noted to have a draining sinus from his amp site and it was eventually found that his PTFE graft was infected. He went to the OR and the majority of the PTFE graft was taken out however a small cuff of graft was left in place at the proximal anastomosis of the groin. Since that operation he has had episodes of bleeding, hematoma, and infection in the left groin. He presented to the emergency room with complaints of spontaneous bleeding from the left groin. He was then taken to the OR for exploration. During the operation cultures were obtained then the groin was opened and washed out. There was no signs of gross infection. The residual PTFE graft was oversewn to stop the bleeding and a sartorius muscle flap was placed over the exposed graft to reduce infection risk. A VAC dressing was then placed. For details of the procedure, please see the surgeon's operative note. The patient tolerated the procedure well without complications and was brought to the post-anesthesia care unit in stable condition. After a brief stay, the patient was transferred to the vascular surgery floor where he remained through the rest of the hospitalization. His wound vac was changed on POD3 and healthy granulation tissue was noted. He was then switched to a wet-to-dry dressing in preparation for discharge to rehab, where a wound vac will again be placed. Infectious Disease was consulted and based on the culture data and sensitivities recommended meropenem while inpatient and discharge on IV Ertapenem 1g q24 for 6 weeks, followed by chronic suppressive oral antibiotics, the course of which will be determined on outpatient OPAT follow-up. He remained afebrile and hemodynamically stable throughout his hospital course, and his WBC remained <10. The patient worked with Physical therapy throughout his hospital course, which recommended rehab. He did have some difficulty with voiding after the Foley was removed, for which his Flomax was increased to 0.8 qhs. He remained A&OX3 and hemodynamically stable throughout his course. On POD 4, the patient was deemed ready for discharge to rehab. He was able to tolerate a regular diet, work with physical therapy, void without issues, and pain was controlled on oral medications alone. He was deemed ready for discharge, and was given the appropriate discharge and follow-up instructions. He will be discharged on IV Ertapenem 1g q24 daily for 6 weeks, he will continue his home dose of Apixaban 5mg BID for history of DVT, he will continue aspirin 81mg daily lifelong, and he will have Tylenol and tramadol for pain control. He will be discharged to rehab for IV antibiotics, wound vac care (black foam at 125mmHg, change every 3 days), and physical therapy. The patient will have appointments set up for Infectious disease, and will follow-up with Vascular surgery in 2 weeks.
summary: You were admitted to the hospital secondary to bleeding from your left groin. Because you have had extensive surgery to the left groin with synthetic graft in the area, we were very concerned that this bleeding was secondary to infection. There was continued oozing so you were taken to the OR for exploration of the left groin. We obtained cultures from the wound in the OR after we washed out the left groin, oversewed the residual graft to stop the bleeding, and covered the area with a muscle flap and placed a VAC to improve healing and reduce the risk of further infection. The infectious disease team was consulted and recommended IV ertapenem 1g q24 for 6 weeks followed by oral suppressive antibiotics. They based this recommendation on the micro-organisms growing from your wound and sensitivities demonstrated.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Mrs. ___ is a ___ year old woman with history of hypothyroidism from pituitary resection, diabetes and recent diagnosis of PMR (___) on chronic prednisone (originally for pituitary resection, increased dose for PMR) who presented with subacute diffuse pain and stiffness, diffuse weakness initially responsive to steroids with subsequent progressive paraparesis, sensory symptoms and bowel and bladder incontinence. Workup has been notable for imaging of spine w enhancing cauda equina nerve roots and lumbar disc herniation. Of note, further review of the imaging by neuroradiology was somewhat inconclusive, and it is unclear if there truly was nerve root enhancement, or possibly just signal from nearby veins. EMG revealed axon loss bilaterally in L3-L4 region without evidence of demyelination. In addition, she has a pro-thrombotic state with multiple DVTs and pulmonary embolism on her imaging, for which we started heparin anticoagulation. During her hospitalization, she underwent LP for diagnostic workup of her cauda equina enhancement, after which she developed an epidural hematoma. She had an IVC filter placed successfully while anticoagulation was held for her surgical intervention. She underwent epidural hematoma evacuation, L3-L5 lumbar decompression, and L4 lumbar laminectomy. Anticoagulation was reinitiated 6 days postoperatively after repeat lumbar MRI and discussing with Neurosurgery. She was discharged home with home Visiting ___. # Hematolgic workup - Hematology was conuslted for cauda equina enhancement in the setting of immune suppression with monoclonal gammopathy - She was worked up for Waldenstrom's, ___ syndrome, and Myeloma, as well as hypercoagulability for DVT/PE, all of which were negative # Lumbar disc herniation - Underwent epidural hematoma evacuation, L3-L5 lumbar decompression, and L4 lumbar laminectomy on ___. Symptoms significantly improved thereafter - follow up with neurosurgery on ___ - prescribed gabapentin for pain # DVT/PE - IVC filter placed, Started on Apixaban 5 mg PO bid Transitional Issues - follow up with Neurosurgery on ___ - Follow up with Neurology in ___ months - Readdress Methotrexate at PCP follow up visit- Held to facilitate Wound healing - Plan for ___ months of anticoagulation for provoked DVT/PE in setting of immobilization - Plan for IVC filter removal at 6 months
summary: You were hospitalized due to symptoms of weakness, sensory changes, and incontinence resulting from lumbar disc herniation. While you were hospitalized, you were found to have a severe stenosis (narrowing of the spinal canal), enhancing cauda equina (signs of inflammation in the nerves), a blood clot in the legs and lungs, and an epidural hematoma (blood clot near the spine). We worked up your cauda equina enhancement with an extensive infectious and proliferative lesion search, which was negative. You underwent surgery for evacuation of your epidural hematoma, and decompression of the stenosis, which improved your symptoms. You also underwent an IVC filter placement for prevention more DVTs from the legs traveling to the lungs and you were started on a Blood thinner called Apixaban.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ year old female with hx of COPD/restrictive lung disease, T1-T2 paraplegia s/p MVA with chronic pain, and recent history of recurrent pneumonias who presents w/ SOB and increased oxygen requirement with CXR concerning for another recurrence of PNA as well as known ESBL UTI. . ACTIVE ISSUES . #. Shortness of breath and O2 requirement: Her decreased neuromuscular strength and inability to clear her secretions could be underlying cause for recurrent infections, despite frequent chest physiotherapy. However, it was considered that this exacerbation may not be infectious, but with the development of hypotension and her O2 requirement, we decided to start broad-spectrum antibiotics initially. CTA chest showed some filling defects in left upper and lower pulmonary vessels (similar to prior) with a new ground-glass opacity on the left suggesting infection. Given her improved clinical status, baseline O2 requirement, lack of fever or leukocytosis, we felt comfortable discontinuing her broad-coverage antibiotics for healthcare associated pneumonia coverage despite this radiological finding. She was continued on albuterol/ipratropium nebs as needed. Her PCA continued to perform chest ___ on her while in house and she did begin to mobilize her secretions. She was discharged off antibiotics. #. CoNS in blood cultures: Blood cultures taken from the PICC line upon admission grew caogulase negative S. aureus. We initially covered with Vancomycin and pulled the PICC line until further data was available. When cultures were repeated, only those from ___ were positive, representing a likely contaminant. The PICC line tip culture itself did not grow anything. She remained afebrile and did not show any systemic signs of infection. . #. Recurrent UTIs: She was admitted on ertapenem for treatment of an ESBL Klebsiella Urine culture showed no growth. Given her spinal cord injury and frequent straight caths, she is prone to UTIs but will not be traditionally symptomatic. She was changed to meropenem on admission. LFTs were checked, given incidence of LFT abnormalities on the penems. She was continued on baclofen, methadone, oxycodone, pregabalin and a bowel regimen of PEG and Dulcolax. Oxybutynin was continued for urinary retention. . #. Hypothyroidism: TSH 10 on last check in ___, resulting in an increase of her levothyroxine dosing. She was continued on levothyroxine at 88mcg daily. . #. Normocytic anemia: At baseline, no evidence of active bleeding. Known anemia of chronic disease. Her Hct was stable in house. . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES . # Follow-up: Ms. ___ will be seen in HCA by ___, NP (Dr. ___ as well as in the pain clinic. Follow-up imaging, as described above, should be arranged for her. . # Communication: Her best friend and PCA ___ (c: ___ was present for the majority of her hospitalization and is intimately involved in her medical care.
summary: You were admitted due to increasing shortness of breath and needing more oxygen at home. We were concerned that you may have another pneumonia, so we initially treated you with additional antibiotics. However, since your laboratory results did not indicate that you had a true infection, we felt comfortable stopping the antibiotics. We also finished your course of antibiotics for your urinary tract infection. We incidentally found organisms in your blood culture that was concerning. However, we determined that this was likely something that was growing in your PICC line itself and we took this out of your arm. Further blood cultures did confirm this.

Your outpatient gastroenterologist requested that you have a colonoscopy done while you were in the hospital. You tolerated a regular diet while you were in the hospital. We changed your medications. We started iron supplementation twice daily. We have also started a stool softener in case you become constipated because of the iron. You should follow-up with your primary care doctor and your gastroenterologist.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ yo man with history of CHF, atrial fibrillation s/p AV nodal ablation now with pacemaker, hypertension, dementia, and prior h/o mechanical falls admitted s/p fall after 1 episode of nonbloody diarrhea and vomiting yesterday in group-home; found to be afebrile in ED with vital signs wnl and imaging studies showing no acute intracranial process or fractures. INR found to be supratherapeutic at 3.9. # S/p fall. Differential diagnosis includes orthostasis in setting of diarrhea and vomiting and likely hypovolemia versus mechanical fall versus cardiogenic cause(arrhythmia, valvular disease) versus vasovagal event versus CNS event. History seems more consistent with orthostasis or mechanical fall, although episode was unwitnessed. CT head in the ED showed no acute process or bleed. Cardiac enzymes were negative x2 ___ hours apart (CK was slightly elevated likely secondary to muscle tissue breakdown- this was downtrending at time of discharge; troponin was also slightly elevated secondary to CKD and remained stable; CK-MB was normal x2). His outpatient cardiologist was contacted by phone and recent TEE report reviewed. This showed globally preserved left ventricular systolic function with no aortic stenosis. Prior to his discharge, patient walked with physical therapy and he was given a walker for use when he returns to the assisted living facility with his wife. His mental status, although initially slightly altered (likely secondary to sleepiness from having been in an ambulance and the emergency room all night), cleared by the second hospital day. Head CT, as above, was unremarkable for acute process. Per family, his mentation was back to baseline at time of discharge. # FEN. Low-sodium, heart-healthy diet. # Prophylaxis. Supra-theraputic on coumadin. # Communication. Daughter (___)- cell: ___ NP (___)- ___ # Code: unknown code-status, assume full code status for tonight # Disposition: discharged back to assisted living
summary: You were admitted after an unwitnessed fall at home. A CT scan of your head showed no signs of bleeding. Blood tests and an EKG showed that you did not have a heart attack. Your heart rhythm was monitored and showed a very brief arrhythmia, but you had no symptoms with this. Initially, you were somewhat sleepy and did not talk much. However, today you seem to be feeling much better and have no current complaints. While you were here, blood tests showed that your INR is elevated from the Coumadin (warfarin) medication that you take. This can cause problems with bleeding. Therefore, we recommend that you stop taking Coumadin until your INR returns to the appropriate level.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ with PMH left frontal cva, htn, pvd, tia, colon cancer, a. fib on coumadin presenting with altered mental status and seizure. # Altered mental status: Pt presented with altered mental status with orientation to self only. We monitored you for 24 hours using an EEG to identify any seizures. EEG did not show seizure activity. The confusion that you had may have been caused by the seizure you had, the many medications you received to treat your seizure, and/or the urinary infection you have. Please take pain medications as needed to help with the pain - this will prevent you from taking shallow breaths because of the pain. text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ year old woman with bipolar disorder, borderline personality disorder, anorexia nervosa with laxative abuse, remote alcohol and cocaine abuse, recent diagnosis of non-Hodgkins lymphoma of the colon (complicating long standing laxative bause), and COPD on 4L who presented with chest pain. text: Brief Hospital Course: PRINCIPLE REASON FOR ADMISSION: Mr. ___ is a ___ w/ complicated past medical history including recent (weeks ago) hemorrhagic strokes and also DVTs with an IVC filter in place, who presents from his rehab facility with right leg swelling, redness and pain, likely representing progression of his clot. summary: It was a pleasure taking care of you. You were admitted for right leg swelling and redness. You had known clots in your legs, for which an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter was previously placed. It seems these clots have progressed further, accounting for the pain, swelling, and even the fever. We do not think you have a skin infection on your leg, and so are not giving you antibiotics. We also found no other evidence of infection. Unfortunately, given your history of brain bleeds, we cannot anticoagulate you, which is the traditional treatment for clots. summary: You came to the hospital for an aortic valve replacement (TAVR). The procedure was successful, and you have a new aortic valve. You were monitored in the Cardiac Care Unit to make sure your blood levels stayed high enough, which they did. The stress test did not identify any abnormalities. We concluded that its likely your pain was not cardiac in nature. Your heart markers being elevated was likely a result of your heart working a little harder while you were in pain. We have not changed any of your medications.

text: Brief Hospital Course: This ___ yo female was admitted on ___ for chest pain and discharged on ___. 1. Atypical chest pain. Patient presents to the hospital with similar symptoms that brought her into the hospital in ___. During that prior hospital course, she received cardiac catheterization which showed similar CAD as prior catheterization, and no intervention was done. Her estimated stress LVEF is slightly lower than the prior echo estimation, but this is somewhat expected given the difference in modality. It is likely that her symptoms is related to GI etiology, such as GERD and esophogeal spasm. She was initiated with a H2 blocker. An endoscopy was recommended to patient, and she decided to have this done in the outpatient basis with her primary care physician. Other possible cause could be small vessel disease, which may be augmented with calcium channel blockers or increase Imdur dose, if her HR and BP tolerates. She was discharged on home medication with the addition of H2 blocker. This can be followed up by patient's primary care physician and her cardiologist. 2. Acute renale failure, likely due to pre-renal. Patient was given fluid while in the hospital, and creatinine improved to baseline by the end of hospital stay. This can be followed up by patient's primary care provider. 3. Asymptomatic urinary tract infection. Routine UA was found to have moderate bacteria. However, patient was asymptomatic without urinary urgency, frequency, or dysuria. Therefore, it is not necessary to treat. This can be followed up by patient's primary care provider. 4. Dyslipidemia. Patient continued with home simvastatin. This can be followed up by patient's primary care provider. 5. Osteoarthritis. Stable. Patient continued to take home darvocet. This can be managed by patient's primary care provider. 6. Insomnia. Stable. Patient remained on home restoril while in the hospital. This can be managed by her primary care provider. 7. Constipation. Stable. She remained on home regimen with Miralax, senna, and colace. This can be managed by her primary care provider.
summary: You were admitted for chest pain. This chest pressure is similar to what you had before in a prior admission, but this is more in the middle of your chest. Your lab work did not show signs of heart attack. Your EKG remained stable while in the hospital. You were evaluated by a nuclear stress test which is reassuring. It is possible that your chest discomfort is due to the small blood vessel disease, esophagus spasm or reflux disease. Evaluation of your digestive tract can be done by your primary care doctor while you are outside of the hospital.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Ms. ___ is a ___ who presented to ___ at 15 weeks gravid with abdominal pain and MRI abdomen/pelvis concerning for acute perforated appendicitis. The Acute Care Surgery service was consulted and the patient was consented for appendectomy. The patient as also seen by the Obstetric team and fetal heart rate and uterus were checked which were normal. On HD2, the patient was taken to the OR and underwent laparoscopic appendectomy with drainage of peritoneal abscess. This procedure went well and the patient remained hemodynamically stable. She was transferred to the surgical floor on IV fluids for hydration, Unasyn, and was made NPO due to the amount of bowel dilation and risk for ileus. The patient received IV acetaminophen PCA morphine for pain control. Foley catheter was removed and the patient voided without issue. Obstetrics did a post-op fetal heart rate check which was normal. Diet was gradually advanced but she had emesis on POD #3. Diet was backed down and then readvanced as tolerated to a regular diet. A bowel regimen was started and the patient had a bowel movement on POD #5. The patient reported right calf pain which she had for the last two days and, although there were no clinical signs of DVT on physical exam, a RLE US was ordered given her risk factors and the US was negative for a DVT. IVF were discontinued, PO oxycodone and acetaminophen were ordered which provided adequate pain relief, augmentin was started which the patient tolerated. The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular and pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. She received subcutaneous heparin for DVT prophylaxis. The patient ambulated early and frequently. At the time of discharge, the patient was hemodynamically stable, afebrile, tolerating a regular diet, voiding without issue and pain was well-controlled. Discharge instructions were reviewed with the patient with verbalized understanding.
summary: You were admitted with abdominal pain and had an abdominal MRI which showed acute, perforated appendicitis. You were taken to the operating room and had your appendix removed laparoscopically. As the inflammation and perforation of your appendix caused dilation of your bowel, you were initially restricted from eating after surgery. You gradually had return of bowel function and are now tolerating a regular diet. Your pain is now better and is controlled with oral pain medication. While in the hospital, you received an intravenous antibiotic called Unasyn (Ampicillin/Sulbactam) to prevent recurrence of infection. This antibiotic was converted to oral Augmentin (Amoxicillin/Clavulanic acid) which you tolerated.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Ms ___ is a ___ year-old female with history of multiple sclerosis who presented to the ED with L flank pain and suffered severe anaphylactoid reaction to IV contrast with acute hypoxia and hypotension while undergoing CT scan; in this setting she received 1 mg 1:1000 IV epinephrine and developed acute lung injury/pulmonary edema and acute myocardial injury for which she was transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit as described above. She was subsequently transferred to the medical floor on ___. Once transferred to the medical floor, her supplemental oxygen was progressively weaned off. Despite persistent symptoms of central chest discomfort following her anaphylactoid event, EKG/enzymes failed to demonstrate ongoing/residual cardiac injury. Ms ___ noted post-prandial nausea/vomiting for several days s/p her ICU stay. She was treated with compazine and zofran with minimal relief. With ongoing symptoms, she received a second dose of compazine on ___ approximately four hours later, the patient developed facial contortion and left hand spasm felt likely to represent an acute dystonic reaction to the compazine. She was treated with benadryl, cogentin, and valium. After approximately ___ hours, her left hand spasm resolved, however Ms ___ remained unable to open her jaw from a closed position despite repeated dosing of benadryl, cogentin, and valium. She was seen by the Neurology Consult Service and also by Dr ___ Oral-Maxillofacial ___. Although initially unable to speak because of concurrent inability to move her tongue, after two days her tongue "loosened" and she was able to communicate verbally despite persistent jaw closure. It was uncertain whether her inability to open the jaw represented trismus vs alternate complication of her dystonic reaction. Ms ___ was observed during sleep with persistent closed jaw, arguing against conversion disorder. She was maintained on IV fluid hydration and liquid diet by straw. Consideration was given to administration of nerve block to facilitate mechanical manipulation to open the jaw, however on ___ her jaw was released from the closed position after 10 mg IV valium and mechanical manipulation by her mother - once released, Ms ___ was able to independently open/close her jaw, eat, and speak without need for further mechanical intervention. In terms of Ms ___ original complaint of left flank pain, Neurology Consult service felt that this most likely represented a thoracic radiculopathy related to a herniated disc. Her symptoms persisted, in waxing/waning intensity, throughout her hospital course. On ___, Ms ___ notice that her right foot was "turning in" (ankle inversion) when she walked; she notes that this is a finding she relates to prior flares of her multiple sclerosis. She also noted "clumsiness" of her right hand, most noticeable in her hand-writing which has become less legible, as well as right eye "blurry vision". A head MRI was obtained which demonstrated new multiple sclerosis disease activity. Upon consultation with Ms ___ primary neurologist, Dr ___ scheduled ___ dose was postponed and she was treated with a 3-day course of intravenous methylprednisolone at a dose of 250mg every 6 hours. Her next scheduled ___ dose was arranged for ___. Repeat echocardiogram ___ demonstrated essentially normal cardiac function, without evidence of pericardial effusion or focal wall motion abnormality.
summary: You were evaluated in the Emergency Department for left-sided flank pain. You had an abdominal CT scan to evaluate this pain, and had a severe allergic "anaphylactoid" reaction to the intravenous contrast used for the CT. You were given a high dose of epinephrine for treatment of this reaction. The severe allergic reaction and high dose of epinephrine resulted in injury to your heart and lungs. You were admitted and treated for this reaction in the Intensive Care Unit, and once stable, transferred to the medicine floor. You also developed a facial contortion and locked jaw (a dystonic reaction) in response to a medication you took for nausea, called Compazine. This resolved initially with medications, except your jaw remained locked. You received Benadryl, Benztropine (Cogentin), and Valium. Higher doses of valium in addition to manual manipulation of your jaw was required to finally open the jaw. You developed symptoms of right ankle inversion, right hand clumsiness, and right eye "blurring". An MRI of your head was consistent with an active multiple sclerosis flare. You were treated with high-dose steroids for three days.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ with HX COPD (on 2L home oxygen), CAD s/p CABG/PCI, severe AS s/p AVR, systolic heart failure and atrial fibrillation WAS transferred from OSH with resolving COPD flare and possible partial SBO, for surgical re-evaluation of his known ventral hernia. . #. summary: You were transferred from an outside hospital for evaluation of your hernia and treatment of your COPD. Your COPD had improved with treatments at the outside hospital even before your arrival here - you were breathing comfortably on your home level of oxygen. We gave you one more dose of an antibiotic and adjusted your medications to match the medications your doctor recommended at your last pulmonary appointment. You continued to do well. Regarding your hernia, we felt that you were stable and without signs or symptoms of bowel obstruction. You were passing stools. Your hernia was not tender. You have previously been evaluated here by surgery; the surgeons, cardiologist, and your primary care doctor all felt surgery was not an option due to your other medical problems.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old gentleman with history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 20%), severe AS, DM and afib on digoxin admitted to CCU in cardiogenic shock, received IV diuresis and transferred to the ___ service, underwent TAVR. Course complicated by right foot hematoma (initially thought to be cellulitis), post-TAVR bradycardia, and asymptomatic hypotension. #Severe Aortic Stenosis s/p TAVR: Peak velocity 3.8 m/sec, peak/mean 54/36, Valve area 0.9 cm2. Symptomatic due to decompensated heart failure. He was declined for surgical AVR. TAVR was thus performed ___ and procedure technically went well. Initially, she went to her PCP at the ___ one day before admission. Her PCP gave her an aspirin, sublingual nitro, and she felt somehwat better. She was then sent to the BI ED and was ruled out for MI. EKGs showed no ST elevations or depressions, 3 sets of troponins were negative at <0.01, 0.02, and <0.01. Her VS: 97.9, 71, 125/73, 18, 98%ra. She had a normal CXR. While she was admitted to the floor, the patient's symptoms resolved and she reported feeling well. We performed a stress EKG test. Patient exercised for 8 minutes of a Modified ___ protocol ___ METs), which was a fair to average exercise tolerance for her age. The test was stopped due to fatigue and patient did not report any anginal symptoms such as chest, neck, back, or arm pain throughout the study. There were no significant ST segment changes during the study. The rhythm was sinus with two isolated VPBs occuring during exercise. Hemodynamic response was appropriate. With the above labs and studies, we ruled out cardiac etiology of her chest pain.
summary: You were admitted for chest pain, associated with left shoulder numbness. Given your symptoms, we investigated the possibility of heart disease. Your cardiac enzymes were negative, suggesting you did not have a heart attack. We also performed a stress test which also was normal, again suggesting that your symptoms are unlikely related to heart disease. It's possible that some of your symptoms might be because of fatigue. Your primary care doctor can help you to treat this condition.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Patient is a ___ year-old right handed man with hx HTN, DM2, CABG, headaches, chronic neck and back pain, p/w right facial numbness, right facial droop and slurred speech x1 day. His examination is notable for rather significant dysarthria but with fluent speech and with naming, repetition, and comprehension intact. He has a right facial droop and limb strength is limited by chronic pain and pre-existing spine disease but appears to have a right hemiparesis and decreased sensation to pinprick in the right hemibody. Given the symptoms, his stroke was likely left basal ganglia versus braintem/pons and further evaluation including MRI of head showed left putamenal infarct. MRA of head and neck showed no critical stenosis or occlusion. Given the risk factors (HTN, HLD, DM and smoking), most likely local stenosis from small vessel atherosclerotic changes. He underwent full stroke evaluation including HbA1C, lipid panel, telemetry and echocardiogram. Given that he was already on ASA, he was switched to Plavix and he was started on Simvastatin 20mg for LDL of 103. He also underwent echocardiogram which showed no evidence of PFO/ASD or thrombus. He also has normal ventricular function with LVEF > 55%. Patient is discharged home with Plavix instead of ASA and addition of Simvastatin for stroke prevention. He is also recommended to undergo speech therapy given significant dysarthria. He is recommended to follow-up with Dr. ___ (___) within 1~2 weeks of discharge. He is also scheduled to follow-up with Dr. ___, neurologist who oversaw his care during this admission.
summary: You were admitted to the hospital after presenting with slurred speech and right facial droop. You underwent stroke evaluation including MRI/A of head and neck which showed left subcortical stroke consistent with your right sided weakness and dysarthria. Your stroke risk factors were evaluated including cholesterol, diabetes and cardiovascular status. Your LDL was 103. Given the stroke and your diabetes, you were started in simvastatin 20mg daily. Also, since you had a stroke while on ASA, your antiplatelet therapy was switched to Plavix daily. You were also evaluated with an echocardiogram which showed no defects to explain for the stroke. Also, you were advised to decrease your stroke risk factor.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Assessment and Plan: This is a ___ year old female who presents with abdominal pain, back pain, and thigh pain. Pain comes and goes and is related to movement. Pt developed chest pain while in the ED. . # Back Pain/Thigh Pain/Abdominal Pain: On admission to the hospital patient noted abdominal pain, back pain, thigh pain. CT in the ED was negative for bowel ischemia. On the floor this pain continued and appeared to be increased when patient worked with ___ and sat up in bed. Neurologically patient noted no change in bowel or bladder habits, sensation and strength intact in lower extremity. Xrays of the hips were negative for fracture or hardware misalignment. Further, xrays of the lumbar spine was negative for fracture. Throughout the admission patients pain was moderately controlled with acetaminophen, lidocaine patches, and warm compresses. Other considerations for pain included myositis, however CK was not elevated. While CT and Xrays did not reveal pathology, soft tissues and nerve roots are poorly visualized with these modalities. Patient is unable to undergo MRI secondary to pacemaker. . #Orthostatic Hypotension: While working with physical therapy patient was found to have a 60 point drop in systolic BP. During this time the patient noted no symptoms of dizziness or lightheadedness. Previous discharge summaries note a similar drop in blood pressure without symptoms. During admission amlodipine was stopped, pt was given compression stockings, and gentle IV rehydration was continued. The day of discharge while working with ___ no orthostasis was noted. . # Chest Pain: While in the emergency department patient had episode of chest pain. No concerning change was noted on EKG. Cardiac enzymes Negative x3. Pt was continued on ASA, Plavix, Isosorbide Mononitrate, and Nitrosublingual as needed for pain. On the floor patient denied chest pain. . #UTI: Urine was noted to have an odor by nursing. UA was positive. Urine culture positive with >100,000 Ecoli. Pt was started on Ciprofloxacin 500mg for 5 days. . # HTN: Pt was initially continued on all of her home hypertension medication including amlodipine and carvedilol. While in the hospital amlodipine was held secondary to orthostatic hypotension.
summary: You were admitted to the hospital with complaints of abdominal, back, and thigh pain. Also, in the emergency department you developed chest pain. On admission to the hospital your abdominal, back, thigh, and chest pain was present. You had some recurrent pain mainly when you got up in bed. In the ED you received a CAT scan which showed that you did not have any decrease in blood flow to your bowels. The CAT scan also showed no other abnormality. Your urine was checked and was positive for infection. In the hospital you were ruled out for a heart attack. Further, x-rays of your hips and lumbar spine were performed and did not show fracture or hardware misalignment. During your stay you developed a urinary tract infection and antibiotics were started.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ with a history of HTN and compensated NASH cirrhosis presenting with bilateral calf pain found to have hypokalemia and acute kidney injury. ACTIVE ISSUES: ============= ___: History is significant for decreased PO intake over two days due to sore throat. Additionally, serum Cr quickly improved in response to IVF. These findings point to a prerenal etiology of ___. #Calf cramping: Most likely due to hypokalemia. CPK is 395, mildly elevated likely in the setting of significant muscle cramps. #Hypokalemia/HypoMagnesium: pt has prior history of hypokalemia requiring potassium supplementation. She has since stopped potassium repletion for unknown reason. Cause of hypokalemia is unclear, although could be related to chronic PPI use causing hypomagnesemia, making it difficult to replete potassium. Will discontinue omeprazole and start H2 blocker on discharge, and will re-initiate potassium supplementation on discharge. #Hypocalcemia/Hypoalbuminemia: Corrected calcium is 8.68. Patient was encouraged to keep up good POs and diet. #Hypophosphatemia: unclear etiology, possibly in the setting of magnesium supplementation and calcium carbonate medication. Pt received 2 packets of neutral-phos repletion prior to discharge. No indication for chronic supplementation given levels >2.0 but should be followed. CHRONIC ISSUES: =============== #Thrombocytopenia: chronic, may be related to history of NASH cirrhosis with depressed TPO synthesis and platelet production. Stable. #Compensated NASH cirrhosis. Warrants re-check as outpatient although levels were not low enough to require chronic supplementation. CORE ISSUES: # CODE STATUS: Full # CONTACT: ___ (son): ___
summary: You came to the hospital because of significant cramping pain in your legs. You were found to have injury to your kidney and low electrolyte levels including phosphorus, potassium, and magnesium. We are not sure why your electrolytes were low but may be because of the omeprazole you were taking. We recommend that you stop this medication. We think the kidney injury occurred because you were dehydrated over the past few days. You were given fluids and electrolyte replacement. Your repeat blood tests showed improvement in your kidney function.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ y/o female with H/O seizure disorder, obesity, and significant tobacco abuse presenting with inconsistently localizable chest pain reproducible by palpation with extension to "whole body." # Chest Pain: No acute cardiac cause identified. Pain lasted over 24 hours at a reported ___ intensity without EKG changes or biomarker elevation for myonecrosis. Also, pain was reproducible on exam, although her history and exam were quite variable from examiner to examiner. Patient was able to fall asleep despite complaints of ongoing pain. She was unable to perform nuclear stress testing due to inability to lay still on her back, which according to the patient is a chronic problem for her. She was also unable to cooperate with a non-imaging exercise stress test. Since ischemia was unlikely given ongoing chest pain without evidence of infarction, other pharmacological stress testing or imaging modalities were not pursued. An echocardiogram was obtained which was unrevealing for any acute wall motion abnormalities but did note grade I diastolic dysfunction. A GI cocktail and PPI did not improve the pain. She was treated with standing Tylenol and ibuprofen for presumed costochondritis. A subclinical seizure leading to fall was a possibility, but CK's were not elevated and pt could not remember any such episode. Patient also had no evidence for pulmonary embolus or aortic dissection by ___ angiogram. The radiology department there felt the 3.9cm ectasia of the ascending aorta seemed chronic and stable and was very unlikely to be causing any of her symptoms. The plan was to have repeat outpatient CT scan of chest in 6 ___ year to assess stability and size. She eventually became pain free prior to discharge. # Seizure disorder- continued divalproex per outpatient schedule # Depression/anxiety - continued quetiapine, clonazepam, escitalopram, and trazodone. Social work was consulted to ensure adequate community resources were available prior to discharge. # Atypical cells on Differential - After discussion with heme/path, the initial report of 12 atypical lymphoctes was changed to 2 reactive lymphcytes, and an automated differentual the next day was reported as negative for atypicals. Plan was to have repeat surveillance WBC differential performed as an outpatient. # Smoking- Patient was given a nicotine patch and encouraged at smoking cessation. Social work was consulted.
summary: You were admitted to the hospital with chest pain. We made sure you did not have a heart attack by checking EKGs and several blood tests. We also made sure you did not have a blood clot in your lungs by performing a special type of imaging. We tried to have you perform different types of stress tests, but you could not lie flat because of chronic back discomfort. You did have an echocardiogram which did not reveal any acute cardiac pathology. Although we are not certain what the cause of your pain is, it is most likely musculoskeletal given that your whole body hurts, and we could reproduce the pain by examining you. The pain is not related to your heart, lungs or major blood vessels in your chest. We incidentally found a small widening of your aorta which is not causing your pain, but it should be monitored with another CT scan to make sure it is not getting bigger. We also found very few atypical blood cells on your bloodwork. These are also not the cause of your pain, but a repeat blood test can be performed as an outpatient to make sure they resolve. We gave you Tylenol and ibuprofen for pain control.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ y/o F w/ CAD, HTN, TIA, HLD presenting to ED w/ AMS and glucose of 704 and found to be in DKA. #DKA: On presentation to the ED, FSBG 705 with 40 ketones/1000 glucose in urine. She was admitted to the ICU where she was aggressively given IVF for hypovolemia, repleted with potassium, and contiued on insulin drip + dextrose until her anion gap was within normal limits at which time the ___ was given her usual basal dose of 15U humalog and put onto lantus sliding scale. She was transferred to the floor where she seen by ___ physicians who helped in adjusting her sliding scale. After one day on the floor her BS were under better control. She no longer had a gap and was tolerating PO. It is unknown what the percipiting event for this ___ DKA was. CXR clear, WBC wnl, U/A clean. LFTs/trop/lipase unremarkable. Now with leukocytosis this AM and low grade fever, but still no clear source of infection. ___ endorses full compliance with home insulin regimen. After discharge, it was noted on her Microbiology results that she had 10,000 GPC in her urine culture. Her UA was negative for infection; suspect colonization or contamination. As she denied any dysuira or urinary symptoms and had a negative UA she was not treated inpatient for a UTI, and was afebrile throughout her stay. summary: You were brought into the hospital for concern that your speech was not making sense and that you might be having a stroke. You were found to have an elevated blood sugar of 704. Neurology saw you and felt that these symptoms were from your elevated blood sugar and not from a stroke. As your blood sugar improved your speech improved. You were admitted to the intensive care unit for diabetic ketoacidosis which can be a life-threatening condition when your blood sugar gets too high. After your condition improved and was no longer critical you were transferred to the general medical floor and we continued to monitor your blood sugars and blood tests. You were tolerating eating and drinking well at the time of discharge. We were unable to figure out why you had such high blood sugars (sometimes it can be caused by infections or not taking medications however you did not have anything on our workup to indicate you have an infection).

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ yo F with hx of HTN, HLD, newly diagnosed MDS, depression and dementia who presented with shortness of breath and lower extremity swelling found to have transudative effusion likely ___ to newly diagnosed CHF. . # Acute on chronic systolic CHF exacerbation: Patient presented with shortness of breath and found to have large right sided pleural effusion. She underwent a thoracentesis which revealed a transudative effusion. Cytology and cultures were negative. The cardiology team was consulted. She had a TTE which showed a mild symmetric LVH with moderate global hypokinesis (EF 35-40%) c/w diffuse process, 4+ TR, mild/mod MR, and pulmonary hypertension. Unclear etiology of new CHF. Ddx includes viral process vs tachycardia mediated cardiomyopathy. She was initially diuresed with IV lasix, however developed ___. When renal function improved she was started on po lasix with good effect. She was continued on her bblocker and ACE inhibitor. She has plans to follow up with cardiology as an outpatient. . # Atrial Fibrillation - Patient found to be in Afib on ECGs and telemetry. Initially it was unclear if it was new or old diagnosis, as there was only an old ECG from ___ showing Afib in OMR. Per cardiology discussion with PCP, ___ is new. summary: You were admitted because you were short of breath. You were found to have fluid in your lungs which was drained off. You underwent an echocardiogram to evaluate the function of your heart which showed that it was not pumping optimally. You were evaluated by the cardiology team and you were started on a medication to help maximize your heart function and improve your symptoms. While you were admitted you were also found to have an abnormal heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation. You were started on a medication called coumadin to help reduce your risk of stroke. This medication will require frequent blood draws for monitoring.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ yo F with h/o gout, bilateral PE on Coumadin, HTN and HLD presents with R knee pain with moderate effusion tapped by ortho in the ED. Differential for knee pain hemarthosis vs gouty flare vs infected prosthesis vs noninflammatory serous fluid collection. #R knee pain: likely a hemarthrosis in setting of elevated INR. Tap in ED showed bloodly fluid of about 5cc. Other concerns are gouty flare, infected prosthesis. Fluid results are WBC 9300, PMN 89%, no crystals, Hct 11.0. This is most consistent with hemarthrosis. GST only showing 2+ PMN's and no organisms. CRP 63.8 but this may be due to prosthetic joint with surrounding effusion. She was seen by ___ and walked with the nurses. ___ recommended home ___ for further strenghtening of her R leg. She experienced no increase in effusion on hospital stay and had a significant decrease in pain and increase in ROM. She was scheduled for follow up with orthopedics. Fluid cultures negative on day of discharge. #Elevated INR: likely due to poor po intake. Warfarin held and INR trended, which was 3.0 on day of discharge. Warfarin restarted a new dose of 1.5 mg daily on discharge. She was scheduled for INR check on ___, day after discharge. #Anemia: macrocytic of 103, H/H ___ from ___ yesterday. Possibly related to poor nutrition. Folate, B12, and TSH levels normal. She remained hemodynamically stable while on the floor. #Shortness of breath: noted on exam ___. CXR performed showed no acute process but rather an extremely large hiatal hernia. Given accompanying GERD, we scheduled outpatient follow up with general surgery to potentially evaluate for surgery. #Gout: continued allopurinol. Low concern for knee being a gouty flare. #H/o bilateral PE: held warfarin as above. #HTN: starting home metoprolol, nifedipine, Lasix, enalapril on admission #HLD: continue rosuvastatin #GERD: omeprazole 20 qd #CKD: baseline Cr 1.7-1.8. She is currently at baseline. Encourage po intake. On day of discharge she had a bump to 2.2, which should be followed up with PCP. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES -Follow up appointments with PCP, ___ (for the hemearthrosis), and General Surgery (hiatal hernia) -Restarting Warfarin on day of discharge ___ at 1.5mg daily (lower than home dose) -Setting up home ___ and ___ -Cr 2.2 on day of discharge, PCP may consider recheck at appointment
summary: You were hospitalized for a swollen and painful right knee. The orthopedics team drained your knee, and this fluid showed blood with no signs of infection. You also had an elevated INR on admission which is the likely cause blood collecting in your knee. Your INR may have been high due to your dose of warfarin being too high, and your low appetite. We had the nurses walk with you to ensure you were back on your feet before going home. We also noticed a hiatal hernia on your chest x-ray, so we are setting up an appointment with a general surgeon for potential management.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ y/o M with DLBCL who presented for scheduled C2 of EPOCH after receiving IT methotrexate the day of admission. # DLBCL - admitted for C2 of EPOCH. Tolerated it well except for hypotension on day 4. Unclear etiology of the hypotension so his chemo was held overnight for 12 hours and then restarted. He completed his chemo without any obvious side effects other than fatigue. Of note, he did receive a bolus of etoposide on the first day in error, but had no side effects from this. The patient had a PICC placed in ___ for access which was removed prior to discharge. He will follow up with Dr. ___ on ___ and is also scheduled for a repeat PET scan that day. # Hypotension - Had asymptomatic hypotension to the ___ during admission. Did not appear infected, but was on high dose pred and could have been hiding fevers, so cefepime started was. Echo done to rule out cardiogenic causes, but it was unchanged from prior. He responded briefly to fluid boluses and to a unit of PRBCs. Then chemo was held for 12 hours. His blood pressure improved and his course was finished. An infectious workup was negative except for a urine culture which grew out E.coli. His blood pressure was stable prior to discharge. # UTI - The patient was cultured for hypotension over the weekend and his urine culture grew out E.coli. He was empirically treated with cefepime and it was planned to discharge him on ciprofloxacin, however his urine culture sensitivities returned after he was discharged with resistance to ciprofloxacin. His wife was contacted and she was told that his antibiotics would need to be changed and a prescription for macrobid ___ mg bid for 10 days was called into their pharmacy. # Sacral decub ulcer - He had no signs of infection, no fevers or chills; wound care was following and his bandage was changed per their recs. He will continue wound care at home with his ___. # Mild dysphagia - He complained of some difficulty getting food stuck in the back of his throat when eating, not changing over time, no thrush on exam. Did fine eating while an inpatient so speech and swallow was not consulted. # Code - full
summary: You were admitted to the hospital to have your second cycle of EPOCH chemotherapy. You had a lumbar puncture and some chemotherapy into your spinal fluid before this admission as well. You tolerated the chemo well. Your blood pressure was slightly low at times. You had no symptoms during these times, and we think it may have been from the chemotherapy. You were found to have a urinary tract infection and are being treated with ciprofloxacin. You should change this medication to Macrobid twice daily for 10 days.

text: Brief Hospital Course: #Left pleural effusion: Pt. p/w new onset L chest pain in setting of recent hospitalization for new pleural effusion. Cytology from the initial pleural effusion tapped during hospitalization in ___ was positive for malignancy consistent with anaplastic thyroid cancer. Her CXR on admission showed total whiteout of L lung, and a L chest tube was placed in ED by IP on ___. On ___ IP performed an thoracoscopy with lysis of adhesions and biopsy of a pleural mass; biopsy pathology returned positive for anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. Her chest tube continued to have high output (~1.5 L per day) and she required IVF for one episode of tachycardia to 120s. She was discharged with stable vital signs, and was able to intake sufficient PO fluids daily. Given the concern for hypotension, her home metoprolol was held and not restarted upon discharge. She was scheduled for close outpatient follow-up with her PCP upon discharge. #SIRS: Pt. was admitted with WBC of 22, lactate 7.2, tachycardia and hypotension, concerning for SIRS/sepsis in the setting of a new pleural effusion. However she remained afebrile and her leukocytosis did not improve on vancomycin and meropenem x5 days. Intravenous fluid resuscitation improved both her hypotension and lactate. Furthermore her pleural cultures were negative for growth. Given these results, oncology and the primary medicine team felt that she had a leukomoid reaction to new metastatic spread of anaplastic thyroid cancer and not sepsis. #Hyponatremia: Presented to the ED with Na 127, compared to 132 at discharge. Serum osm ~264. Urine Na was low. Likely hypovolemic in setting of SIRS, with elevated lactate. Her serum Na improved with fluid resuscitation. # Anaplastic thyroid cancer: Cause of pleural effusion given prior cytology and biopsy showing anaplastic cells. Patient was seen by at___ oncology on prior admission. Atrius oncology was notified that the patient was in house and will see her as an outpatient and will follow-up with her regarding the results of her biopsy. #Transitional issues -needs to follow up with PCP to address whether to restart metoprolol and assess volume status -needs close follow up to ensure she is taking adequate PO fluids due to high pleurex output. Consider outpatient IVF if hypovolemic. -Has pleurex capped to be drained by ___. Please drain sterily qd and please do not drain more than 1L at one time. See instructions on page 1. -needs further evaluation for staging and treatment of metastatic anaplastic thyroid cancer. Pathology of a pleural mass is positive for anaplastic thyroid.
summary: You were admitted with pain in your left chest and were found to have a pleural effusion on chest x-ray. Our interventional pulmonologists placed a chest tube to help drain the effusion. After the tube was placed it showed a high output and you were able to breathe more comfortably. You also underwent a procedure to biopsy a mass in your pleural space. When you were admitted, your bloodwork showed that your white blood cell count was very high. We started you on two antibiotics, vancomycin and meropenem, to help cover possible bacterial infections. However, you did not have fevers and your pleural fluid cultures did not show any evidence of infection; therefore, these antibiotics were stopped. We came to the conclusion that your elevated white cell count was in response to your pleural effusion and mass in your pleural space.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Mr ___ was a ___ male with decompensated hepatitis C virus infection and resultant cirrhosis with portal hypertension, ascites and peripheral edema (s/p TIPS) who was awaiting transplant. He presented from ___ for rising Bilirubin in the setting of multiple evolving medical problems. During this hospitalization patient's end stage liver disease continued to decompensate and his course was further complicated by development of hepatorenal syndrome, persistent leukocystosis, and eventually development of sepsis which led to his death. Below is a brief outline of some of the major medical issues that affected his course. #) End Stage Liver Disease: Secondary to hepatitis C cirrhosis. Patient had severe decompensation of liver disease over the course of this hospitalization. Encephalopathy worsened likely given an underlying infection of unclear source in spite of being on broad antibiotic coverage for much of his hospitalization. Bilirubin continued to trend up. He underwent MRCP that did not indicate any obstructing stones though he was noted to have a large pancreatic pseudocyst. Course also complicated by the development of hepatorenal syndrome eventually requiring dialysis. By the end of patient's hospitalization MELD score was greater than 40. Patient required a liver transplant, however, transplant was no longer an option when patient's white count began to rise and it was determined by abdominal ultrasound that he was found to have multiple liver lesions that appeared to be abscesses. Patient's family agreed to make him DNR/DNI given his poor prognosis. #) Persistent Leukocytosis: WBC count elevated for most of this admission. He was found to have a blood culture positive for Coagulase Negative Staph on ___ and was treated with a course of Vancomycin. He had many negative urine, stool, peritoneal cultures, and subsequent blood cultures that were negative. Patient was on broad coverage antibiotics including vancomycin, meropenem and micafungin for a significant portion of his hospitalization. He was only noted to be febrile sporadically. The infectious disease team, who followed the patient, had a high level of suspicion that the patient's pancreatic pseudocyst could have been infected. Towards the end of the ___ hospital course his white count rose precipitously as high as 48. As explained above, an ultrasound of his liver demonstrated multiple liver lesions that may have been abscesses. #) Hepatorenal Syndrome: Patient course was complicated by the development of hepatorenal syndrome. Creatinine initially responded to albumin and fluids but then began to increase precipitously and it was at this point that octreotide and midodrine were initiated. Hemodialysis was eventually initiated. Patient had been listed for a kidney transplant. #) Bullous disorder of unclear etiology: The patient presented with a bullous skin lesions on the trunk and lower legs felt by dermatology to be most consistent with drug-induced bullous pemphigoid. He was s/p extended stay in the ___ burn unit for treatment of these lesions. Though the patient had an exposure to chloroquine prior to admission the dermatology team did not feel that these lesions were completely consistent with a chloroquine bullous reaction. They also considered lasix as a potential cause. Lesions remained stable with wound care and treatment with clobetasol. Patient did have a re-exposure to lasix on ___ and subsequently developed a morbiliform drug hypersensitivity reaction on the skin with no worsening of the bullous eruption. This new eruption was mainly managed with medication for pruritus.
summary: The patient was admitted for management of his end stage liver disease secondary to hepatitis C. During this admission he was also evaluated for bullous skin lesions that could be secondary to chloroquine ingestion. His hospitalization was also complicated by development of hepatorenal syndrome. He was being considered for liver transplantation until he began to develop sepsis. Cultures including stool and urine remained negative though patient had a known pseudocyst that may have ultimately been the source of infection. Prior to his death patient was noted to have diffuse cystic lesions throughout his liver that were likely abscesses. Given his critical condition his family decided to make DNR/DNI though antibiotics were continued. Patient was pronounced dead during the hospitalization.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Mrs. ___ is a ___ yo right handed female who presents with seizure-like events on a background of significant and long standing bipolar disorder on lithium and opiate abuse on methadone. On this admission she had two typical episodes which were captured on video monitoring and had no EEG correlate. The EEG video shows the events starting with arm shaking, and then spreading to the whole upper body with head shaking from side to side. The patient is closes her eyes and nonverbal during these episodes, but able to nod her head upon question. She is AAOx3 immediately after the event. NO seizures were recorded during the events. As these events are non-epileptic in nature we discussed the diagnosis of pseudoseizure with her and her mother and they appeared to agree and understand that she does not have a dangerous underlying neurological problem. We attempted to contact her psychiatrist and faxed her a copy of the discharge records. summary: You were admitted due to events concerning for possible seizure. Your convulsion events may be a manifestation of stress and may be related to your psychiatric illnesses. With your permission we contacted your psychiatrist to inform her of your admission and workup and we will defer further psychiatric management to her as outpatient. text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ y/o female with CAD, CHF, CKD, and DM2 who was admitted for hyponatremia. # Hyponatremia/Polydipsia: Etiology of hyponatremia secondary to polydipsia as the patient admitted to drinking excess water. She is afraid she will need dialysis in the future, therefore drinks water whenever she feels her urine output is not adequate. This is supported by dilute urine osmolality on admission (144). The patient was placed on fluid restriction of 1.5L and her sodium trended to normal upon discharge. Patient also has an element of volume overload secondary to systolic CHF. Therefore, torsemide was restarted at her previous dose (5mg). The patient was informed that her kidney function is stable, and she should continue with 2L fluid restriction. # Hyperkalemia: K+ peaked at 5.6 during this admission. EKG did not have any hyperacute T waves. Per OMR, the patient may type IV distal RTA. This is evidenced by history of hyperkalemia as well as urine pH >5. Irbesartan was decreased by half to prevent further episodes of hyperkalemia. The patient was also restarted on torsemide. # Systolic CHF: Secondary to coronary artery disease. Repeat echo with EF 50-55%, though EF was 34% on perfusion stress test. BNP was elevated, though at baseline. Patient appeared asymptomatic and compensated, though volume status was difficult to assess due to body habitus. The patient's carvedilol was increased to 25mg BID as she was hypertensive. Irbesartan dose was also decreased in half. Patient was restarted on torsemide 5mg (previous home dose). # Coronary artery disease: The patient had one episode of chest pain with radiation down her left arm. EKG and troponins were negative. Echocardiogram showed decreased EF and new hypokinesis in the inferior walls. Stress test did not produce angina or EKG changes. Perfusion stress test was unremarkable. The patient was continued on aspirin and simvastatin. Cardiology was consulted and felt patient may have an element of demand ischemia in the setting of hypertension. Therefore, carvedilol dose was increased to 25mg BID. Patient was also started on imdur 30mg. # Hypertension: Patient was hypertensive with SBP up to 180s. Therefore carvedilol dose was increased to 25mg BID. Irbesartan was decreased to 37.5mg due to hyprekalemia. Imdur 30mg was also started. # Chronic Kidney Disease Stage III: The patient's baseline Cr is 1.4, though ranges from 1.3-1.6. As above, counseled patient that her Cr has remained stable and we don't anticipate her needing dialysis in the near future. # DM Type II on insulin: HbA1c 6.7 in ___. The patient only takes glargine when her FSBG is >200. The patient's sugars were well controlled and she never required insulin. # Anemia of chronic disease: H/H remained stable. She was continued on ferrous sulfate. # Crohn's Disease: The patient was continued on sulfasalazine and ciprofloxacin. # Peptic ulcer disease: Patient was continued on omeprazole. # Alcoholic cirrhosis: No evidence of decompensation. Last EGD ___ with no evidence varices. # Chronic pancreatitis: Continued on creon. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - The patient will follow up with Cardiology. - Please repeat Chem 7 at ___ appointment. - Encourage patient to adhere to 2L fluid restriction. - Carvedilol dose increased to 25mg BID. - Patient started on imdur 30mg as patient remained hypertensive. - Irbesartan dose decreased to 37.5mg due to hyperkalemia, and patient has a history of type IV renal tubular acidosis. - Patient restarted on torsemide 5mg. - Consider decreasing aspirin dose to 81mg.
summary: As you recall, you were admitted and your sodium was found to be low. Your low sodium is due to your excess water intake. Your kidney function tests have been stable, therefore we do not anticipate you needing dialysis in the near future. Please limit your water intake to 2L per day (equivalent to the size of one large soda bottle). As discussed, excess water will cause your sodium to be low, which can be dangerous. It can also cause your heart function to worsen. You also had some chest pain in the hospital. EKGs and lab tests indicate no acute damage to your heart. You had an echocardiogram, which showed your heart function is decreased from prior tests. Because of this, we increased the dose of carvedilol and started you on a new blood pressure medication called Imdur. Your irbesartan dose was decreased by half to prevent your potassium too be high. We also restarted you on torsemide to decrease swelling in your legs.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ who is a quadriplegic due to MVA ___ years ago, with chronic draining sinus on left elbow s/p washout x2 who presents with increased purulence and drainage from left elbow. # Left Elbow Infection: patient has a history of left elbow infection which has been treated with washout x2 in the past, resulting in chronic draining sinus. text: Brief Hospital Course: Ms. ___ is a ___ with past medical history of dermatitis but with otherwise no past psychiatric or neurological history presenting following an episode of sudden behavioral arrest. Patient initially was brought to the emergency department at ___ by EMS following an episode of unresponsiveness to voice or touch, but without rhythmic movements of the eyes, face, or limbs. While in the emergency department, she remained in this state but would resist examination, and was unable to cooperate with a CT scan. She was given a total of 4 mg IM lorazepam and 10 mg IM haloperidol in the emergency room and was minimally reactive and unable to provide history or participate in physical exam upon initial consultation. Patient was subsequently hospitalized for further evaluation. A non-contrast head CT showed slightly enlarged ventricles but was otherwise unremarkable. CXR was unremarkable. Laboratory studies did not demonstrate any toxic, metabolic, or infectious cause. The next morning, the patient was alert and oriented to person, place, month and year, and situation. Her sister and the patient both reported that she was back to her neurological baseline. Patient's physical exam was non-focal, and her laboratory studies continued to be unremarkable. cvEEG showed a normal background and no epileptiform activity. MRI w/wo contrast did not show acute intracranial abnoramility or other structural or vascular cause of her presenting symptoms. Patient did acknowledge recent depressive symptoms due to considerable recent stress financially and physically at work, for which a social work consult was obtained. She denies desire to self harm, suicidal ideation, homicidal ideation, and audiovisual hallucinations. Upon further discussion with social work, it was discovered she has experienced significant past trauma and non-consensual sexual encounters. Social work is assisting on setting patient up with further resources including trauma resources, therapy at the ___ Violence Prevention, Therapy for Dissociation, Support Groups and possibly psychiatry Differential diagnosis for the patient's symptoms initially included non-convulsive status or complex partial seizures with postictal state, limbic encephalitis, psychogenic non-epileptic seizure. However, given the patient's normal cvEEG without evidence of epileptiform discharges and her unremarkable toxic, metabolic, infectious, and structural findings on our thorough work-up, it appears that a provoked or unprovoked seizure is unlikely in this patient. Moreover, given the patient's rapid improvement the next day, limbic encephalitis is unlikely. It is likely that the patient's recent social and physical stressors are underlying her current presentation. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: =============================================== - Follow up with PCP ___ 1 week after discharge - Will need monitoring of mood and safety - Social work following and looking to establish further resources including trauma resources, therapy at the ___ Violence Prevention, Therapy for Dissociation, Support Groups and possibly psychiatry
summary: You presented to the hospital with an episode of unresponsiveness, for which you were admitted for further evaluation. While in the hospital, you had laboratory studies, a CT scan of your head, an MRI of your head, and an EEG (which monitors the electrical activity of your brain). The CT and MRI of your brain was without acute abnormalities that would explain your symptoms. Your EEG showed normal electrical activity of your brain. Your lab work did not show a toxic metabolic or infectious source of your symptoms. The morning after admission, you expressed you felt back to your baseline. During your admission, social work was involved in finding resources to ensure that you have support and safety upon discharge. They are working to set up different resources for you including Trauma Resources and therapy at the center for Violence Prevention.

text: Brief Hospital Course: # The patient was admitted with fevers to 103 and right sided hip pain from OSH in the setting of recent IVDU. Orthopedics and ID did not feel strongly about need for aspirating the joint given initial response to antibiotics. You had blood cultures that showed that you had a bloodstream infection with a bacteria called "Strep Viridans". Given this infection and a heart murmur heard on exam, you were started on antibiotics and underwent a "TEE" of your heart which showed bacteria on one of your heart valves (the mitral valve). Repeat MRI of your hip and your lower spine showed a fluid collection. The orthopedics were involved but there did not appear to be any areas of inflammation or fluid that aspiration would help more than antibiotics.

text: Brief Hospital Course: This is a ___ year old gentleman with history of hepatitis C infection and ESRD on HD who presents with thrombosed graft. # Clotted AV Fistula: Patient came from ___ clinic with inability to canulate the AV graft on the left arm. Also, during your admission, we found that you have low blood levels including low levels of platelets (blood cells that help your blood clot), and white blood cells (cells that help your body fight infection). text: Brief Hospital Course: Pt is a ___ YO M with h/o stage IV double-hit DLBCL s/p R-EPOCH ___ s/p IT MTX ppx x4 and currently on high-dose MTX for leptomeningial recurrance presents to the ER with exacerbation of severe back pain with radiation to his legs. . . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES # Reimaging is recommended for previously seen adrenal mass with adrenal protocol as an outpatient. # MRA neck should be done to evaluate internal carotid artery.
summary: You were admitted due to severe pain in your lower back that radiated down both your legs. You were started on steroid treatment and an MRI was done of your spine. It showed that the leptomeningeal involvement of the lymphoma was stable. Therefore, you were started on cycle #2 of high-dose methotrexate, as well as rituximab. You tolerated these treatments well and cleared your methotrexate well. Of note, you were found to have a mass on your left adrenal gland and a small defect in an artery on the left side of your neck, both of which should be followed up with imaging as an outpatient.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ year old male on eliquis for prothrombin gene mutation admitted to the General Surgical Service on ___ for evaluation and treatment of worsening left groin pain and larger bulge at hernia site. Admission abdominal/pelvic CT revealed incarcerated inguinal hernia that requires reduction and hernia repair. Since there is no evidence of strangulation, the patient was taken to the operating room after 36 hours of Eliquis washout. The patient underwent repair left inguinal and spigelian hernia with mesh, which went well without complication (reader referred to the Operative Note for details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the floor tolerating sips, on IV fluids, and oral analgesia for pain control. The patient was hemodynamically stable. POD1 a heparin drip was started. The Foley was removed but the patient was unable to void. He was started on Flomax and the Foley was replaced for urinary retention. POD2, it was noted that the patient was developing a large hematoma beneath the surgical incision. The heparin drip was stopped. Hematocrit drifted from 33 to 28. The patient was otherwise hemodynamically stable. The hematoma was monitored closely. JP drain output remained serosanguinous with moderate output. Hematocrit remained stable. Eliquis was restarted on ___. The patient was converted to oral pain medication with continued good effect. Diet was progressively advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. During this hospitalization the patient worked with ___, who recommended discharge to rehab. The Foley was removed and another void trial was attempted, but the patient was unable to void so the Foley was reinserted. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating with a walker and assist, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient was discharged home without services. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.
summary: You were admitted with groin pain from an incarcerated hernia. You were taken to the operating room and underwent hernia repair with mesh. After surgery, a blood thinner was restarted and you developed a large hematoma at the surgical site. Your anticoagulation was then stopped while the bleeding stopped. Your blood counts are stable and the hematoma was monitored closely. Your Eliquis is now restarted. After your Foley catheter was removed, you experienced urinary retention and were unable to void. The Foley has been reinserted and you were started on Flomax, a medication to help relax the ureters and help you void. We are recommending you be discharged to rehab to regain your strength.

text: Brief Hospital Course: In the ED, initial vs were: 98.4, 75, 117/79, 20, 98% on RA. Patient was given a banana bag, valium 5mg and 60meq of po potassium for a K of 2.8. His labs showed an elevated AST at 86, ALT of 45, T-bili of 2.5, his bicarb was elevated at 38, serum and urine tox screens were both negative. He was then admitted for alcohol withdrawal.
